documentation_quality.value: Good — adequate documentation, covers main features

assessment.strongest_capability_justification: Industry-standard yield cleaning with 12+ error types, multi-combine calibration, and one-click pipeline. Class calibration platform.
assessment.weakest_capability_justification: Limited public API; strong file-based workflow but fewer live integrations than cloud platforms.
assessment.worst_suited_for: Operations that need real-time cloud sync and mobile-first workflows.
assessment.unique_differentiator: OEM-independent; ingests and exports to all major equipment brands. Desktop-first with robust yield and VRA tools.
assessment.recommendation: Yes — strong recommendation for the right operation
assessment.ai_notable_error: AI overstated API availability; actual API is partner-only.

evidence_log.hands_on_notes: Tested SMS Advanced v22.10 trial on Windows. Imported yield and shapefiles; ran yield cleaning and generated VRA prescription. Exported to ISOXML and shapefile.

individual_animal_records.value: Yes — individual animal tracking with unique ID

value: Health & treatment records with withdrawal periods
traceability_birth_to_harvest.notes: CCIA integration claimed by AI but NOT verified — see ai_notable_error.

api_availability.value: Public API — documented, open to third parties

hardware_dependency.value: Fully software-independent — all core features work without proprietary hardware (manual uploads, API, third-party connections)

standardized_cost_livestock_annual.notes: Est. 500 head cow-calf; USD converted to CAD.

documentation_quality.value: Good — adequate documentation, covers main features

assessment.strongest_capability_justification: End-to-end livestock records: individual animal ID, RFID, breeding, health, grazing, weight tracking, and gross margins. Strong in Australian market.
assessment.weakest_capability_justification: No broadacre/yield/ISOXML; limited Canadian regulatory integrations (e.g. CCIA) compared to TELUS ARM.
assessment.worst_suited_for: Grain-only or row-crop operations that need yield maps and VRA prescriptions.
assessment.unique_differentiator: Livestock-first platform with 25%+ of Australia's grazing animals; mobile crush-side; cost of production and gross margins per head.
assessment.recommendation: Conditionally — good for specific use cases (explain in notes)
assessment.ai_notable_error: AI claimed CCIA (Canadian Cattle Identification Agency) integration; vendor documentation and support did not confirm this. May be planned or region-specific.

evidence_log.hands_on_notes: Tested AgriWebb subscription (web + mobile). Created paddocks, added animal records, grazing moves, and weight entries. Did not verify CCIA integration (AI hallucination).

assessment.strongest_capability_justification: Best used ariel for crop analysis, for both vegetative index (NDVI), physical monitoring (lidar), and basic photo imagery. The data collection is entirely dependent on which sensors the drone has.
assessment.weakest_capability_justification: Seems to lack native capabilities to process data such as the kringing or other delineation methods, would make the system much more capable.
assessment.worst_suited_for: Small farms and retailers, really no value for the cost. As well livestock I just cant see the value for those operations.
assessment.unique_differentiator: It seems to have many industry standard integrations as well as being able to transfer data through open source platforms, making it fairly open and capable.
assessment.ai_notable_error: It sometimes seems to assume something is true just because there isn't a source that explicitly says otherwise. Example being integration, it seems to hallucinate companies that do integrate just because there is nothing that says they don't.

source_types_used: Independent blog or review (e.g., PrecisionAg, AgFunder)
evidence_log.hands_on_notes: I was not able to try the platform as there is no free option, as well you need a real company to try the free trial that needs a payment method. As such there was no hands on testing performed.

standardized_cost_broadacre_notes.value:
The following pricing strucure exists based on farm size:
250 - 750	ac $0.8
750 - 2.5Kac	$0.72
2.5K - 12.5Kac	$0.64
12.5K - 25Kac	$0.56
25K+ac	Contact Geopard for special offer

cost_to_leave.value: Free — full data export, no penalty

documentation_quality.value: Excellent — comprehensive knowledge base, searchable, regularly updated

update_frequency.value: Sporadic, ranging from monthly to every 5 months

assessment.strongest_capability: Satellite imagery and vegetation index analysis
assessment.strongest_capability_justification: Automated multi-year satellite analytics, 12+ vegetation indices, 3D topography, AI-based zone delineation, and API-first architecture make it a best-in-class analytics engine.
assessment.weakest_capability_justification: No farm financial management, no accounting software integration, no income tracking; cost equations exist but a full profitability analysis suite is absent
assessment.worst_suited_for: Livestock producers, there is no functionality for their needs
assessment.unique_differentiator: Best-in-class bi-directional John Deere Operations Center integration, white-label/API-first architecture enabling other AgTech companies to embed its analytics engine, and automated multi-year field productivity mapping.
assessment.recommendation: Conditionally — good for specific use cases (explain in notes)
assessment.ai_notable_error: Claude did not recognise the languages available, saying it is only available in English, Spanish, and Ukranian. Chat GPT  only made 3 claims in total

evidence_log.hands_on_notes:
Created farm, fields, field boundaries.
 Created management zones from historical satellilte NDVI data. 
Connected to John Deere Operations Center.
Created  soil sampling plans.
Imported yield data.
Exported  management plans, soil sampling plans.
Created reports

identity.version_module_evaluated: Operations Center — free tier, accessed Feb 2026; Field Analyzer, Mapping

yield_monitor_import.notes: Native JD telematics and file upload.

direct_machine_telematics.notes: Requires JDLink MTG for auto sync.

ease_of_import.notes: Easy with JD equipment; manual upload for others.

value: Fertilizer rate prescriptions (N, P, K, S, micronutrients)

api_availability.value: Public API — documented, open to third parties

hardware_dependency.value: Enhanced by proprietary hardware — manual uploads work, but automated data sync / telematics require specific hardware (specify which)
hardware_dependency.notes: JDLink MTG required for real-time telematics.

data_ownership_policy.value: User owns data, platform has license to use for service delivery

data_portability.value: Full export — all raw and processed data downloadable in standard formats

free_tier_available.notes: Basic tier free; premium tiers for more acres/features.

standardized_cost_broadacre_annual.notes: Free tier covers 2000 ac basic; premium est. $1,500–3,000 CAD.

documentation_quality.value: Excellent — comprehensive knowledge base, searchable, regularly updated

assessment.strongest_capability_justification: Excellent telematics and machine data ingestion when using JD equipment; strong satellite imagery integration; open API for third-party data.
assessment.weakest_capability_justification: Best experience is JD-only; mixed-fleet users need workarounds. API exists but AI overstated ease of non-JD integration.
assessment.worst_suited_for: Mixed-fleet operations that need brand-agnostic data without manual uploads.
assessment.unique_differentiator: Tight integration with John Deere equipment and Sentera imagery; freemium tier; strong Canadian presence.
assessment.recommendation: Yes — strong recommendation for the right operation
assessment.ai_notable_error: AI claimed broader third-party API integration than documented; several integration claims were partner-only or required custom dev.

evidence_log.hands_on_notes: Tested Operations Center free tier (web + mobile). Uploaded shapefile and CSV; viewed yield maps. Did not have JDLink MTG so telematics not tested hands-on.

identity.company_developer: QGIS Development Team / Open Source Geospatial Foundation

company_developer.value: QGIS Development Team / Open Source Geospatial Foundation

unit_system_handling.value: Fully supports Imperial, Metric, and Canadian mixed units seamlessly

data_format_limitations.value: No native ISOXML/ISOBUS, ag machine data, or yield monitor format support; requires manual conversion for most precision ag proprietary formats. Requires 3rd party plugins

ease_of_import_reason.value: QGIS is fairly drag and drop in many cases. If it is not drag and drop there is many import wizards within the program that make it very easy. Also because it is open source there is lots of recourses that show you how to import all types of data

value: Filter by buffer zone (around a feature)

profit_loss_map.comment: No native native functions, you could probably do all of this using user defined functions

yield_map_generation_notes.value: Can create yield maps from imported point data via interpolation, but no native yield cleaning or yield map workflow

export_geospatial.comment: Not all formats have been listed, just the ones used most for agriculture

export_tabular.comment: Not all formats have been listed, just the ones used most for agriculture

batch_export.value: Must export layer-by-layer within each field

time_to_first_map.comment: Based heavily on experience, but a new user with some data ready can get a map fairly easy

api_availability.value: Public API — documented, open to third parties

data_format_interoperability.comment: Has the most geospatial format support possible

hardware_dependency.value: Fully software-independent — all core features work without proprietary hardware

data_ownership_policy.value: User owns all data (clearly stated in terms)

data_portability.value: Full export — all raw and processed data downloadable in standard formats

data_deletion_policy.value: User can delete all data at any time (self-service)

data_sharing_third_parties.value: No sharing — data is never shared with third parties

ag_data_transparent.comment: It is local and open source, not certified, but not an issues

data_storage_location.comment: There is cloud options but it is through plugins or user defined work and means

sharing_advisors.comment: You can send file and findings. You can send the project file but you will need to make sure it is repackages properly so the other user can see it

offline_functionality.value: Full offline — all features available without internet

onboarding_setup.comment: Difficult for non-GIS users; steep learning curve; significant GIS knowledge assumed. Lots of online recourses

documentation_quality.value: Excellent — comprehensive knowledge base, searchable, regularly updated
documentation_quality.comment: Vast official documentation as well as community knowledge

update_frequency.value: Long Term release annually; regular releases every 4 months; point releases more frequently

assessment.strongest_capability_justification: QGIS provides world-class geo spatial output, supports 300+ data formats via GDAL/OGR, and offers unmatched flexibility for spatial visualization and analysis
assessment.weakest_capability_justification: QGIS has zero financial management,  it is a GIS platform, not a precision ag management platform.
assessment.worst_suited_for: Farmers wanting an all in one farm management software
assessment.unique_differentiator: completely free and open-source with unrivaled geospatial format support. Massive plugin capabilities. Not locked to any vendor
assessment.recommendation: Yes — strong recommendation for the right operation
assessment.ai_notable_error: Not really any QGIS is well documented
